qas.question: What do Type-A receptacles do on host devices?
What do Type-b receptacles do on target devices?
What do the receptacles prevent user from doing?

answers.text: from accidentally connecting two USB power supplies to each other

qas.question: What networks do USB not support?

context: The standard connectors were deliberately intended to enforce the directed topology of a USB network: Type-A receptacles on host devices that <a0_0>supply power<a0_0/> and Type-B receptacles on target devices that <a1_0>draw power<a1_0/>. This prevents users <a2_0>from accidentally connecting two USB power supplies to each other<a2_0/>, which could lead to short circuits and dangerously high currents, circuit failures, or even fire. USB does not support <a3_0>cyclic networks<a3_0/> and the standard connectors from incompatible USB devices are themselves incompatible.
